You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: despite rising commodity and energy prices amid solid growth outlook, consumer and core inflation rates are moderate across the globe.\n                '}]

"justification": "The sentence reports moderate inflation rates despite rising commodity and energy prices, suggesting that inflationary pressures are under control, which may support expansionary monetary policy."

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in june, consumer prices decreased by 0.51 percent, bringing annual consumer inflation down by about 0.9 points to 7.20 percent.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence reports a decrease in consumer prices and a decline in annual consumer inflation, suggesting a slowdown in price pressures and potentially supporting an expansionary monetary policy stance."
}

inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: as announced in the 2023 monetary policy and liraization strategy document, the committee will continue to decisively use the tools supporting the effectiveness of the monetary transmission mechanism; and the entire policy toolset, particularly funding channels, will be aligned with liraization targets.\n                '}]

decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: all in all, the seasonally-adjusted underlying trend of core goods inflation posted a significant increase mostly due to exchange rate pressures.\n                '}]

sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: that of vehicle loans fell by 0.59%, maintaining its weak course since the beginning of the year.\n                '}]

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it has become even more important to keep financial conditions supportive to preserve the growth momentum in industrial production and the positive trend in employment after the earthquake.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 22:42:04,917 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence emphasizes the need to maintain supportive financial conditions to preserve growth momentum and a positive trend in employment, suggesting a dovish stance to promote economic growth."
}

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: furthermore, the newly-restored relations with russia translated into a boost for exports.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence reports a boost in exports, which may lead to a trade surplus, potentially justifying a looser monetary policy stance."
}

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: recent data show that economic activity in the earthquake zone continued to recover faster than expected, thereby largely compensating for the disaster-driven contraction.\n                '}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the global supply chain pressure index converged to its historical trend in november, while international transportation costs remained low in this period.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 22:42:13,384 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence reports a convergence of global supply chain pressure to its historical trend and low international transportation costs, suggesting reduced inflationary pressures and potential room for accommodative monetary policy."
}

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: following the rise in january, the seasonally and calendar adjusted industrial production index declined by 6% on a monthly basis in february due to the earthquake.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence reports a decline in industrial production, suggesting a potential slowdown in economic activity, which may support expansionary monetary policy."
}

states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in seasonally and calendar-adjusted terms, october production figure was flat compared to the previous month, but 1.0 percent higher than the third-quarter average.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reports a flat production figure compared to the previous month and a slight increase compared to the third-quarter average, indicating a stable economic condition without any clear bias towards tightening or easing policy."
}

inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: regarding portfolio flows to emerging economies, bond and equity markets have both continued to register outflows in july in line with the global risk appetite.\n                '}]

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: strengthening domestic demand due to the lagged effects of strong credit impulse during the pandemic, affects the current account balance adversely through the imports channel.\n                '}]

Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: annual inflation recorded some decline in the services group, but increased in other subgroups.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 22:42:33,930 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports a mixed inflation picture, with a decline in one subgroup but an increase in others, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{cbrt}{6} Economic Status, Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY), Inflation Rates, Interest Rates, Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy, and Foreign Trade Balance.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item Economic Status: Represents the overall condition of the Turkish economy, including inflation, unemployment, and growth trends.\n    \\item Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY): Fluctuations in the value of the Turkish lira relative to other currencies, influencing trade and inflation.\n    \\item Inflation Rates: Measures the rate of price increases for goods and services in Turkey, impacting purchasing power and policy decisions.\n    \\item Interest Rates: The CBRT\'s benchmark policy rate, affecting borrowing costs, investment, and overall economic activity.\n    \\item Government Debt \\& Fiscal Policy: Represents Turkey’s government borrowing levels and fiscal management, influencing monetary policy choices.\n    \\item Foreign Trade Balance: Measures Turkey’s exports and imports, with trade surpluses or deficits impacting currency strength and policy decisions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Thus, the unemployment rate declined by 0.4 points compared to previous month and realized as 9.6\\%.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The sentence reports a decline in unemployment, potentially justifying a more hawkish approach to curb inflation.\n\n    \\item ``Thus, the rise in automobile prices amounted to 34.01\\% in the first six months of 2023.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights a significant increase in automobile prices, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee has therefore decided to keep the interest rates at current levels.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence simply states that interest rates will remain unchanged, reflecting no immediate bias toward tightening or easing policy.\n    \n    \\item ``Annual inflation remained flat in rents, but decreased in other subgroups.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: With inflation showing stability in rents and declines elsewhere, the overall price pressure appears subdued, which may support expansionary monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``In sum, economic activity is expected to recede in the third quarter.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This forward-looking forecast of a slowdown in economic activity points to the possibility of an easing monetary stance to promote economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Impact analyses of the CBRT\'s regulations are conducted for all components of the framework by assessing their impact on inflation, interest rates, exchange rates, reserves, expectations, securities, and financial stability with a holistic approach.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence focuses on a comprehensive evaluation process of regulatory impacts without providing any specific insight into monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Turkey}}\n\\label{tb:cbrt_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n%\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n%\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation is decreasing, unemployment is rising, or economic growth is weak. & When inflation is increasing, unemployment is low, and economic growth is strong. & When economic indicators remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Currency Exchange Rate (Turkish Lira - TRY)} & When the lira depreciates significantly, increasing import costs and inflationary pressure. & When the lira appreciates, reducing import costs and signaling potential monetary tightening. & When the exchange rate remains stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Rate} & When inflation is slowing down, suggesting room for rate cuts. & When inflation is rising, requiring tighter monetary policy. & When inflation remains within the target range. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, any increase in M2, demand for loans is higher. & High money supply, demand for goods increase, demand for loans decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Government Debt} & When government debt increases significantly, prompting expectations of monetary stimulus to manage borrowing costs. & When debt decreases, indicating fiscal discipline and allowing tighter monetary policy. & When debt levels remain stable. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Trade Balance} & When the trade deficit widens, indicating higher imports than exports, potentially justifying a weaker lira and looser monetary policy. & When the trade deficit narrows or a surplus is recorded, strengthening the lira and allowing for tighter policy. & When the trade balance remains relatively unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & When the sentiment is growth oriented, e.g., "accommodative," "maximum employment," "price stability," "heightened consumption," "low inflation." & When sentiment is restrictive, indicating a focus on "price stability" and "sustained growth." & Use of neutral terms, e.g., "mixed," "moderate," "reaffirmed." & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: accordingly, the committee decided to take one more measured step towards simplification by lowering the marginal funding rate.\n                '}]

"justification": "The sentence indicates a decision to lower the marginal funding rate, which is a step towards easing monetary policy, suggesting a dovish stance."

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2.
